Since every function in G+\mathscr G_+G+​ is of the form g(Y),g(Y),g(Y), we get

E[h(X)∣G]=∫Th(t) κ(Y,dt).\begin{aligned} \mathbb{E}[h(X) \mid \mathscr G] = \int_{\mathsf T} h(t) \, \kappa(Y, \mathrm{d}t).\end{aligned}E[h(X)∣G]=∫T​h(t)κ(Y,dt).​

Now if f∈(S⊗T)+f \in (\mathscr S \otimes \mathscr T)_+f∈(S⊗T)+​ is such that it is the product f=g⋅h,f = g \cdot h,f=g⋅h, then since g(Y)g(Y)g(Y) is G−\mathscr G-G−measurable, we get

E[f(Y,X)∣G]=g(Y)E[h(X)∣G]=g(Y)∫Th(t) κ(Y,dt)=∫Tf(Y,t) κ(Y,dt).\begin{aligned} \mathbb{E}\left[f(Y,X) \mid \mathscr G\right] = g(Y) \mathbb{E}[h(X) \mid \mathscr G] = g(Y)\int_{\mathsf T} h(t) \, \kappa(Y, \mathrm{d}t) = \int_{\mathsf T}f(Y, t) \, \kappa(Y, \mathrm{d}t).\end{aligned}E[f(Y,X)∣G]=g(Y)E[h(X)∣G]=g(Y)∫T​h(t)κ(Y,dt)=∫T​f(Y,t)κ(Y,dt).​

Finally, a monotone class argument finishes the proof.

Although we won’t be needing it, let me briefly mention the notion of generalized disintegration.

Definition 7 (General disintegration): Let (E,E)(\mathsf E, \mathscr E)(E,E) and (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr{S})(S,S) be measurable spaces, ψ ⁣:E→S\psi \colon \mathsf E \to \mathsf Sψ:E→S be a measurable mapping, γ\gammaγ be a measure on (E,E),(\mathsf E, \mathscr E),(E,E), and μ\muμ be a measure on (S,S).(\mathsf S, \mathscr S).(S,S). We call a kernel κ\kappaκ from (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr{S})(S,S) to (E,E)(\mathsf E, \mathscr{E})(E,E) a (ψ,μ)−(\psi, \mu)-(ψ,μ)−disintegration of γ\gammaγ if

  1. κx{ψ≠x}=0\kappa_x\{\psi \neq x\} = 0κx​{ψ=x}=0 for μ−\mu-μ−a.e. xxx, and

  2. we have the following iterated integral for each f∈E+,f \in \mathscr E_+,f∈E+​,

∫Ef dγ=∫S(∫Ef(y) κx(dy))μ(dx).\begin{aligned} \int_{\mathsf E} f \, \mathrm{d}\gamma = \int_{\mathsf S} \left( \int_{\mathsf E} f(y) \,\kappa_x(\mathrm{d}y) \right) \mu(\mathrm{d}x).\end{aligned}∫E​fdγ=∫S​(∫E​f(y)κx​(dy))μ(dx).​

Note that, because of property 1, we can write (6) as

∫Ef dγ=∫S(∫{ψ=x}f(y) κx(dy))μ(dx).\begin{aligned} \int_{\mathsf E} f \, \mathrm{d}\gamma = \int_{\mathsf S} \left( \int_{\{\psi=x\}} f(y) \,\kappa_x(\mathrm{d}y) \right) \mu(\mathrm{d}x).\end{aligned}∫E​fdγ=∫S​(∫{ψ=x}​f(y)κx​(dy))μ(dx).​

The disintegration discussed in Theorem 3 is a special case of the disintegration discussed in Definition 7. To see this, let (E,E)(\mathsf E, \mathscr E)(E,E) be the product space (S×T,S⊗T)(\mathsf{S} \times \mathsf T, \mathscr S \otimes \mathscr T)(S×T,S⊗T) and ψ ⁣:S×T→S\psi \colon \mathsf S \times \mathsf T \to \mathsf Sψ:S×T→S be the canonical projection. {ψ=x}\{\psi = x\}{ψ=x} is then simply T\mathsf TT and equation (6) becomes equation (3).

The following existence theorem is taken from Pollard’s book (Pollard, 2010).

Theorem 5: Under the setting of Definition 7, assume that

  1. (E,E)(\mathsf E, \mathscr E)(E,E) is a metric space endowed with its Borel σ−\sigma-σ−algebra,

  2. γ\gammaγ and μ\muμ are σ−\sigma-σ−finite with γ\gammaγ being a Radon measure (i.e., γ(K)<∞\gamma(K) < \inftyγ(K)<∞ for each compact KKK and γ(B)=sup⁡K⊆Bγ(K),\gamma(B) = \sup_{K \subseteq B} \gamma(K),γ(B)=supK⊆B​γ(K), the supremum being taken over compact sets, for each B∈EB \in\mathscr EB∈E),

  3. the image measure γ∘ψ−1\gamma \circ \psi^{-1}γ∘ψ−1 of γ\gammaγ under ψ\psiψ is absolutely continuous with respect to μ,\mu,μ, and

  4. the graph ⟦ψ⟧:={(y,x)∈(E,S):ψ(y)=x}\llbracket \psi \rrbracket := \{(y,x) \in (\mathsf E, \mathsf S) : \psi(y) = x\}[[ψ]]:={(y,x)∈(E,S):ψ(y)=x} is contained in the product σ−\sigma-σ−algebra E⊗S.\mathscr E \otimes \mathscr S.E⊗S.

Then γ\gammaγ has a (ψ,μ)−(\psi, \mu)-(ψ,μ)−disintegration κ\kappaκ, unique up to a μ−\mu-μ−equivalence, in the sense that if κ‾\overline \kappaκ is another (ψ,μ)−(\psi, \mu)-(ψ,μ)−disintegration, then μ{x∈S:κx≠κ‾x}=0.\mu\{x \in \mathsf S : \kappa_x \neq \overline\kappa_x\} = 0.μ{x∈S:κx​=κx​}=0.

As an example of a Radon measure, every σ−\sigma-σ−finite measure on the Borel σ−\sigma-σ−algebra of a Polish space which assigns finite measure to compact sets is Radon.

As a curiosity check out lifting theory.

MARKOV DECISION PROCESS

Markov Decision Model

Let us start by defining the moving parts of a Markov decision process. Our model evolves through time such that we can observe the state of the model and take admissible actions at discrete times n=0,1,2,….n = 0, 1, 2, \ldots.n=0,1,2,…. We will say n≥0n \ge 0n≥0 to mean nnn is a non-negative integer.

State Space

We denote by Sn\mathsf{S}_nSn​ the state space of the model at time n≥0.n \ge 0.n≥0. We will assume that for each n≥0n \ge 0n≥0, Sn\mathsf{S}_nSn​ is a standard Borel space endowed with its Borel σ−\sigma-σ−algebra.

Action Space

We denote by An\mathsf A_nAn​ the action space at time n≥0.n \ge 0.n≥0. This is the set from which possible actions can be chosen at time n.n.n. It is possible that the admissible actions at time nnn is a strict subset of An\mathsf A_nAn​ depending on the state of the model. We will again assume that for each n≥0n \ge 0n≥0, An\mathsf A_nAn​ is a standard Borel space endowed with its Borel σ−\sigma-σ−algebra.

Admissible Actions

For each n≥0n \ge 0n≥0, we have a mapping

αn ⁣:Sn→An\begin{aligned} \alpha_n \colon \mathsf S_n \to \mathscr A_n\end{aligned}αn​:Sn​→An​​
from the state space Sn\mathsf S_nSn​ to the measurable subsets of the action space An\mathsf A_nAn​, which assigns to each x∈Snx \in \mathsf S_nx∈Sn​ the set αn(x)\alpha_n(x)αn​(x) of admissible actions. We will assume that
⟦αn⟧∈Sn⊗An,∀ n≥0,\begin{aligned} \llbracket\alpha_n\rrbracket \in \mathscr S_n \otimes \mathscr A_n, \quad \forall \; n \ge 0,\end{aligned}[[αn​]]∈Sn​⊗An​,∀n≥0,​
and that
there exists a measurable fn ⁣:Sn→An such that ⟦fn⟧⊆⟦αn⟧,∀ n≥0.\begin{aligned} \text{there exists a measurable } f_n \colon \mathsf S_n \to \mathsf A_n \text{ such that } \llbracket f_n \rrbracket \subseteq \llbracket \alpha_n \rrbracket, \quad \forall \; n \ge 0.\end{aligned}there exists a measurable fn​:Sn​→An​ such that [[fn​]]⊆[[αn​]],∀n≥0.​
Here the notation

⟦αn⟧:={(x,a)∈Sn×An∣a∈αn(x)}⟦fn⟧:={(x,a)∈Sn×An∣a=fn(x)}\begin{aligned} \llbracket\alpha_n\rrbracket &:= \{(x,a) \in \mathsf S_n \times \mathsf A_n \mid a \in \alpha_n(x)\} \\ \llbracket f_n\rrbracket &:= \{(x,a) \in \mathsf S_n \times \mathsf A_n \mid a= f_n(x)\} \end{aligned}[[αn​]][[fn​]]​:={(x,a)∈Sn​×An​∣a∈αn​(x)}:={(x,a)∈Sn​×An​∣a=fn​(x)}​

denotes the graphs of αn\alpha_nαn​ and fnf_nfn​ respectively. For a justification of these assumptions, see the section below ??

Transition Law

For each time n≥0n \ge 0n≥0, we have a stochastic kernel

κn ⁣:⟦αn⟧×Sn+1→[0,1]\begin{aligned} \kappa_n \colon \llbracket\alpha_n\rrbracket \times \mathscr S_{n+1} \to [0,1]\end{aligned}κn​:[[αn​]]×Sn+1​→[0,1]​
from the graph ⟦αn⟧\llbracket\alpha_n\rrbracket[[αn​]] (endowed with the Borel σ−\sigma-σ−algebra on the subspace topology) to Sn+1\mathsf S_{n+1}Sn+1​, called the transition law. Therefore, if at time nnn the model’s state is xnx_nxn​ and we took an admissible action ana_nan​, then the probability of finding the model in state B∈Sn+1B \in \mathscr S_{n+1}B∈Sn+1​ at time n+1n+1n+1 is κn((xn,an),B).\kappa_n((x_n, a_n), B).κn​((xn​,an​),B).

Reward Function

For each time n≥0n \ge 0n≥0, we have a measurable reward function

rn ⁣:⟦αn⟧×Sn+1→[−∞,∞).\begin{aligned} r_n \colon \llbracket \alpha_n \rrbracket \times \mathsf S_{n+1} \to [-\infty, \infty).\end{aligned}rn​:[[αn​]]×Sn+1​→[−∞,∞).​
For (xn,an)∈⟦αn⟧(x_n, a_n) \in \llbracket \alpha_n \rrbracket(xn​,an​)∈[[αn​]] and xn+1∈Sn+1x_{n+1} \in \mathsf S_{n+1}xn+1​∈Sn+1​, rn((xn,an),xn+1)r_n((x_n, a_n), x_{n+1})rn​((xn​,an​),xn+1​) models the reward received at time nnn when at state xnx_nxn​ the admissible action ana_nan​ was taken and the system transitioned to state xn+1.x_{n+1}.xn+1​. Under many performance criteria, it will suffice to model the rewards using r‾n ⁣:⟦αn⟧→[−∞,∞)\overline r_n \colon \llbracket \alpha_n \rrbracket \to [-\infty, \infty)rn​:[[αn​]]→[−∞,∞) which we can get from rnr_nrn​ (assuming appropriate integrability) using
r‾n(x,a)=∫Sn+1rn((x,a),y)κn((x,a),dy),\begin{aligned} \overline r_n(x,a) = \int_{\mathsf S_{n+1}} r_n((x,a),y) \kappa_n((x,a), \mathrm{d}y),\end{aligned}rn​(x,a)=∫Sn+1​​rn​((x,a),y)κn​((x,a),dy),​
and, in fact, moving forward, we will assume that rnr_nrn​ has the form
rn ⁣:⟦αn⟧→[−∞,∞).\begin{aligned} r_n \colon \llbracket \alpha_n \rrbracket \to [-\infty, \infty).\end{aligned}rn​:[[αn​]]→[−∞,∞).​

Stationary Markov Decision Model

The sequence

{(Sn,An,αn,κn,rn)}n≥0\begin{aligned} \left\{\left(\mathsf S_n, \mathsf A_n, \alpha_n, \kappa_n, r_n\right)\right\}_{n \ge 0}\end{aligned}{(Sn​,An​,αn​,κn​,rn​)}n≥0​​
of tuples defined above is called the non-stationary Markov decision model. We can find an equivalent stationary Markov decision model (S,A,α,κ,r)(\mathsf S, \mathsf A, \alpha, \kappa, r)(S,A,α,κ,r) from a non-stationary Markov decision model by a standard augmentation procedure:

Define the tuple (S,A,α,κ,r)(\mathsf S, \mathsf A, \alpha, \kappa, r)(S,A,α,κ,r) as follows:

S:={(x,n)∣x∈Sn,n≥0},A:={(a,n)∣x∈An,n≥0},S∋(x,n)↦α((x,n)):={(a,t)∈A∣a∈αn(x)},κ(((x,n),(a,n)),{(b,n+1)∣b∈B}):=κn((x,a),B),B∈Sn+1,⟦α⟧∋((x,n),(a,n))↦r((x,n),(a,n)):=rn(x,a).\begin{aligned} \mathsf S &:= \{(x,n) \mid x \in \mathsf S_n, n \ge 0\},\\ \mathsf A &:= \{(a,n) \mid x \in \mathsf A_n, n \ge 0\},\\ \mathsf S \ni (x,n) \mapsto \alpha((x,n)) &:= \{(a,t) \in \mathsf A \mid a \in \alpha_n(x)\}, \\ \kappa(((x,n), (a,n)), \{(b,n+1) \mid b \in B\}) &:= \kappa_n((x,a), B), \quad B \in \mathscr S_{n+1}, \\ \llbracket \alpha\rrbracket \ni ((x,n), (a,n)) &\mapsto r((x,n), (a,n)) := r_n(x,a). \end{aligned}SAS∋(x,n)↦α((x,n))κ(((x,n),(a,n)),{(b,n+1)∣b∈B})[[α]]∋((x,n),(a,n))​:={(x,n)∣x∈Sn​,n≥0},:={(a,n)∣x∈An​,n≥0},:={(a,t)∈A∣a∈αn​(x)},:=κn​((x,a),B),B∈Sn+1​,↦r((x,n),(a,n)):=rn​(x,a).​

We will thus assume a stationary Markov decision model from now on.

Definition 8: A Markov decision model is a tuple

(S,A,α,κ,r)\begin{aligned} (\mathsf S, \mathsf A, \alpha, \kappa, r)\end{aligned}(S,A,α,κ,r)​
consisting of

  1. the state space S\mathsf SS which is a standard Borel space;

  2. the action space or the control space A\mathsf AA which is a standard Borel space;

  3. the mapping α ⁣:S→A\alpha \colon \mathsf S \to \mathscr Aα:S→A from the state space to the measurable subsets of the action space, which assigns to each x∈Sx \in \mathsf Sx∈S the set α(x)\alpha(x)α(x) of admissible actions satisfying the assumptions: ⟦α⟧∈S⊗A,\begin{aligned} \llbracket\alpha\rrbracket \in \mathscr S \otimes \mathscr A,\end{aligned}[[α]]∈S⊗A,​ there exists a measurable f ⁣:S→A such that ⟦f⟧⊆⟦α⟧;\begin{aligned} \text{there exists a measurable } f \colon \mathsf S \to \mathsf A \text{ such that } \llbracket f \rrbracket \subseteq \llbracket \alpha \rrbracket;\end{aligned}there exists a measurable f:S→A such that [[f]]⊆[[α]];​

  4. the stochastic kernel κ\kappaκ from the graph ⟦α⟧\llbracket \alpha \rrbracket[[α]] of α\alphaα to S\mathsf SS called the transition law; and

  5. the measurable reward function r ⁣:⟦α⟧→[−∞,∞).r \colon \llbracket \alpha \rrbracket \to [-\infty, \infty).r:[[α]]→[−∞,∞).

A Note About Admissible Actions

The raison d'être for the assumptions (7) and (8) is to avoid measurability hell. This is the topic of measurable selection theorems. I discussed these theorems under special cases in two previous blog posts for their applications to general theory of processes (they are called section theorems there which means the same thing as selection theorems).

Let us very briefly discuss measurable selection in a general setting. Let (T,T)(\mathsf T, \mathscr T)(T,T) be a measurable space, X\mathsf XX be a topological space, and ϕ ⁣:T→P(X)\phi \colon \mathsf T \to \mathfrak{P}(\mathsf X)ϕ:T→P(X) be a set-valued function (also called a multifunction or a correspondence) taking values in the class of all subsets of X.\mathsf X.X. We say that a multifunction ϕ\phiϕ is closed if ϕ(t)\phi(t)ϕ(t) is closed for each t∈T.t \in \mathsf T.t∈T. Note that ϕ\phiϕ can be equivalently identified with a subset of T×X.\mathsf T \times \mathsf X.T×X. A selection (also called a section) of ϕ\phiϕ is a function f ⁣:T→Xf \colon \mathsf T \to \mathsf Xf:T→X such that f(t)∈ϕ(t)f(t) \in \phi(t)f(t)∈ϕ(t) for each t∈T.t \in \mathsf T.t∈T. If ϕ(t)≠∅\phi(t) \neq \varnothingϕ(t)=∅ for each t∈Tt \in \mathsf Tt∈T, then at least one selection exists by the axiom of choice. Note that writing ⟦f⟧⊆⟦ϕ⟧\llbracket f \rrbracket \subseteq \llbracket \phi \rrbracket[[f]]⊆[[ϕ]] is same as saying fff is a selection of ϕ.\phi.ϕ. If we denote

S(ϕ):={f ⁣:T→X∣f is a measurable selection of ϕ},\begin{aligned} \mathfrak{S}(\phi) := \{f \colon \mathsf T \to \mathsf X \mid f \text{ is a measurable selection of }\phi\},\end{aligned}S(ϕ):={f:T→X∣f is a measurable selection of ϕ},​
then measurable selection theorems tell us when S(ϕ)\mathfrak{S}(\phi)S(ϕ) is nonempty. Note that if the σ−\sigma-σ−algebra T\mathscr TT is P(T),\mathfrak{P}(\mathsf T),P(T), for example if T\mathsf TT is countable, then any function f ⁣:T→Xf \colon \mathsf T \to \mathsf Xf:T→X satisfying ⟦f⟧⊆⟦ϕ⟧\llbracket f \rrbracket \subseteq \llbracket \phi \rrbracket[[f]]⊆[[ϕ]] is measurable.

To be able to study measurability of selections it seems natural to first define measurability of multifunctions, and then relate the two notions. It turns out doing so isn’t straightforward. But before we get to measurability, we need a notion of inverse for multifunctions, of which there are two natural ones. The upper inverse ϕ∗\phi^{*}ϕ∗ and the lower inverse ϕ∗\phi_*ϕ∗​ are defined by

ϕ∗(A):={t∈T:ϕ(t)⊆A},A⊆X,ϕ∗(A):={t∈T:ϕ(t)∩A≠∅},A⊆X.\begin{aligned} \phi^*(A) &:= \{t \in \mathsf T : \phi(t) \subseteq A\}, \quad A \subseteq \mathsf X, \\ \phi_*(A) &:= \{t \in \mathsf T : \phi(t) \cap A \neq \varnothing \}, \quad A \subseteq \mathsf X. \end{aligned}ϕ∗(A)ϕ∗​(A)​:={t∈T:ϕ(t)⊆A},A⊆X,:={t∈T:ϕ(t)∩A=∅},A⊆X.​

Note that ϕ∗(A)=X∖ϕ∗(X∖A)\phi^*(A) = \mathsf X \setminus \phi_*(\mathsf X \setminus A)ϕ∗(A)=X∖ϕ∗​(X∖A), and therefore we can equivalently use either of the two inverses to define measurability notions. We say that ϕ\phiϕ is

  1. weakly measurable, if ϕ∗(G)∈T\phi_*(G) \in \mathscr Tϕ∗​(G)∈T for each open G⊆XG \subseteq \mathsf XG⊆X;

  2. measurable, if ϕ∗(F)∈T\phi_*(F) \in \mathscr Tϕ∗​(F)∈T for each closed F⊆XF \subseteq \mathsf XF⊆X;

  3. Borel measurable, if ϕ∗(B)∈T\phi_*(B) \in \mathscr Tϕ∗​(B)∈T for each Borel subset B⊆X.B \subseteq \mathsf X.B⊆X.

For the inverses we have that

ϕ∗(⋂i∈IAi)=⋂i∈Iϕ∗(Ai) and ϕ∗(⋃i∈IAi)=⋃i∈Iϕ∗(Ai),\begin{aligned} \phi^*\left(\bigcap_{i \in I} A_i\right) = \bigcap_{i \in I}\phi^*(A_i) \text{ and } \phi_*\left(\bigcup_{i \in I} A_i\right) = \bigcup_{i \in I}\phi_*(A_i),\end{aligned}ϕ∗(i∈I⋂​Ai​)=i∈I⋂​ϕ∗(Ai​) and ϕ∗​(i∈I⋃​Ai​)=i∈I⋃​ϕ∗​(Ai​),​

but unlike functions, the inverses of multifunctions don’t behave well with complements, thereby necessitating three notions of measurability above.

The most well-known measurable selection theorem is the Kuratowski–Ryll-Nardzewski selection theorem, which states that a weakly measurable closed multifunction into a Polish space admits a measurable selection. It can be shown that a weakly measurable closed multifunction into a separable metrizable space has measurable graph (in the product σ−\sigma-σ−algebra), and conversely if a closed multifunction into a separable metrizable space is compact-valued such that its graph is measurable, then it is weakly measurable. The converse allows usage of Kuratowski–Ryll-Nardzewski selection theorem to justify existence of a measurable selection. This explains why many papers and books in control, instead of having the lazy assumption (8), assume that the mapping α\alphaα in definition 8 is compact-valued, an assumption which also has the advantage of being more explicit and avoiding inconsistencies.

Assumption (8) circumvents bringing conditions for measurable selection theorems in our discussion ahead, while assumption (7) allows us to define κ.\kappa.κ. For more details check the two review papers (Wagner, 1977), (Wagner, 1980) or Chapter 18 of the book (Aliprantis and Border, 2006).

Policy

A policy π={πn}n≥0\pi = \{\pi_n\}_{n \ge 0}π={πn​}n≥0​, also known as an admissible control, is a sequence of prescriptions πn\pi_nπn​ that at time nnn gives a rule for selecting an action. πn\pi_nπn​ can be a randomized procedure or a deterministic procedure; it can depend on the entire history of the model or only on the current state. Let us formalize this concept.

History

Definition 9: For each time n≥0n \ge 0n≥0, define the space Hn\mathsf H_nHn​ of admissible histories up to time nnn by H0=S\mathsf H_0 = \mathsf SH0​=S, and
Hn=S×⟦α⟧n=Hn−1×⟦α⟧,n≥1.\begin{aligned} \mathsf H_n = \mathsf S \times \llbracket \alpha \rrbracket ^n = \mathsf H_{n-1} \times \llbracket \alpha \rrbracket, \quad n \ge 1.\end{aligned}Hn​=S×[[α]]n=Hn−1​×[[α]],n≥1.​

An element hn∈Hnh_n \in \mathsf H_nhn​∈Hn​ is of the form hn=(x0,a0,x1,a1,…,xn−1,an−1,xn).h_n = (x_0, a_0, x_1, a_1, \ldots, x_{n-1}, a_{n-1}, x_n).hn​=(x0​,a0​,x1​,a1​,…,xn−1​,an−1​,xn​).

Definition 10: A policy π={πn}n≥0\pi = \{\pi_n\}_{n \ge 0}π={πn​}n≥0​ is a sequence of stochastic kernels πn\pi_nπn​ from Hn\mathsf H_nHn​ to A\mathsf AA subject to the constraint πn(hn,α(xn))=1,∀ hn∈Hn,n≥0.\begin{aligned} \pi_n(h_n, \alpha(x_n)) = 1, \quad \forall \; h_n \in \mathsf H_n, n \ge 0.\end{aligned}πn​(hn​,α(xn​))=1,∀hn​∈Hn​,n≥0.​ The set of all policies is denoted by Π.\Pi.Π.

Classes of Policies

The largest class of policies we consider is Π\PiΠ defined above. If instead of using the entire history, the policy makes a decision using only the current state, then we get a Markov policy.

Definition 11: If a policy π={πn}n≥0∈Π\pi = \{\pi_n\}_{n \ge 0} \in \Piπ={πn​}n≥0​∈Π is such that for each n≥0n \ge 0n≥0, there exists a stochastic kernel φn\varphi_nφn​ from S\mathsf SS to A\mathsf AA such that
πn(hn,⋅)=φn(xn,⋅),∀ hn=(x0,a0,…,xn−1,an−1,xn)∈Hn,\begin{aligned} \pi_n(h_n, \cdot) = \varphi_n(x_n, \cdot), \quad \forall \; h_n = (x_0, a_0, \ldots, x_{n-1}, a_{n-1}, x_n) \in \mathsf H_n,\end{aligned}πn​(hn​,⋅)=φn​(xn​,⋅),∀hn​=(x0​,a0​,…,xn−1​,an−1​,xn​)∈Hn​,​
then π\piπ is called a Markov policy. We denote the set of all Markov policies by ΠM.\Pi_M.ΠM​.

We will sometimes abuse notation and write π={φn}n≥0\pi = \{\varphi_n\}_{n \ge 0}π={φn​}n≥0​ for a Markov policy, where φn\varphi_nφn​ are the stochastic kernels as above. Even more simply, if our policy at each time doesn’t depend on the time but only on the current state, we get a stationary policy. A stationary policy is necessarily Markovian.

Definition 12: If a policy π={πn}n≥0∈Π\pi = \{\pi_n\}_{n \ge 0} \in \Piπ={πn​}n≥0​∈Π is such that there exists a stochastic kernel φ\varphiφ from S\mathsf SS to A\mathsf AA such that for each n≥0n \ge 0n≥0,
πn(hn,⋅)=φ(xn,⋅),∀ hn=(x0,a0,…,xn−1,an−1,xn)∈Hn,\begin{aligned} \pi_n(h_n, \cdot) = \varphi(x_n, \cdot), \quad \forall \; h_n = (x_0, a_0, \ldots, x_{n-1}, a_{n-1}, x_n) \in \mathsf H_n,\end{aligned}πn​(hn​,⋅)=φ(xn​,⋅),∀hn​=(x0​,a0​,…,xn−1​,an−1​,xn​)∈Hn​,​
then π\piπ is called a stationary policy. We denote the set of all stationary policies by ΠS.\Pi_S.ΠS​.

What about deterministic policies?

Definition 13: A policy ϕ={fn}n≥0\phi = \{f_n\}_{n \ge 0}ϕ={fn​}n≥0​ is called a deterministic policy if it is a sequence of measurable functions fn ⁣:Hn→Af_n \colon \mathsf H_n \to \mathsf Afn​:Hn​→A such that fn(hn)∈α(xn)f_n(h_n) \in \alpha(x_n)fn​(hn​)∈α(xn​) for all hn∈Hnh_n \in \mathsf H_nhn​∈Hn​ and n≥0.n \ge 0.n≥0. We denote the set of deterministic policies by ΠD.\Pi_D.ΠD​. Similar to definitions 11 and 12, we can define the class of deterministic Markov policies ΠDM\Pi_{DM}ΠDM​ and deterministic stationary policies ΠDS.\Pi_{DS}.ΠDS​.

The set Π\PiΠ contains these deterministic policies, as can be easily seen by observing that for the deterministic policy ϕ={fn}n≥0\phi = \{f_n\}_{n \ge 0}ϕ={fn​}n≥0​ the corresponding policy π={πn}n≥0\pi = \{\pi_n\}_{n \ge 0}π={πn​}n≥0​ is given by

πn(hn,C)=δfn(hn)(C),hn∈Hn,C∈A.\begin{aligned} \pi_n(h_n, C) = \delta_{f_n(h_n)}(C), \quad h_n \in \mathsf H_n, C \in \mathscr A.\end{aligned}πn​(hn​,C)=δfn​(hn​)​(C),hn​∈Hn​,C∈A.​

We thus have the following inclusions:

ΠDS⊆ΠS⊆ΠM⊆Π, ΠDS⊆ΠDM⊆ΠD⊆Π, ΠDM⊆ΠM.\begin{aligned} \Pi_{DS} \subseteq\Pi_S \subseteq \Pi_{M} \subseteq \Pi, \; \Pi_{DS} \subseteq \Pi_{DM} \subseteq \Pi_{D} \subseteq \Pi, \; \Pi_{DM} \subseteq \Pi_{M}.\end{aligned}ΠDS​⊆ΠS​⊆ΠM​⊆Π,ΠDS​⊆ΠDM​⊆ΠD​⊆Π,ΠDM​⊆ΠM​.​

Canonical Construction

A natural question now arises to the suspicious reader about the existence of a probability space on which the random quantities discussed above are from. More precisely:

Given a Markov decision model (S,A,α,κ,r)(\mathsf S, \mathsf A, \alpha, \kappa, r)(S,A,α,κ,r), a policy π∈Π,\pi \in \Pi,π∈Π, and a probability measure ν\nuν on S\mathsf SS, does there exist a probability space (Ω,F,Pνπ),(\Omega, \mathscr{F}, \mathbb{P}_{\nu}^{\pi}),(Ω,F,Pνπ​), and two stochastic processes {Xn}n≥0\{X_n\}_{n \ge 0}{Xn​}n≥0​ and {An}n≥0\{A_n\}_{n \ge 0}{An​}n≥0​ on this probability space, with the random variable XnX_nXn​ taking values in S\mathsf SS and the random variable AnA_nAn​ taking values in A\mathsf AA for each n≥0n \ge 0n≥0, such that the following three properties hold true?

  1. The law of X0X_0X0​ equals ν\nuν, i.e.,

    Pνπ{X0∈B}=ν(B),B∈S.\begin{aligned} \mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi\{X_0 \in B\} = \nu(B), \quad B \in \mathscr S.\end{aligned}Pνπ​{X0​∈B}=ν(B),B∈S.​

  2. If Hn=(X0,A0,…,Xn−1,An−1,Xn) ⁣:Ω→HnH_n = (X_0, A_0, \ldots, X_{n-1}, A_{n-1}, X_n) \colon \Omega \to \mathsf{H}_nHn​=(X0​,A0​,…,Xn−1​,An−1​,Xn​):Ω→Hn​ denotes the history random variable, the joint distribution of (Hn,An)(H_n,A_n)(Hn​,An​) is given by (Pνπ∘Hn−1)⊗πn.(\mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi \circ H_n^{-1}) \otimes \pi_n.(Pνπ​∘Hn−1​)⊗πn​. More intuitively, by Theorem 4, this means that the stochastic kernel π‾n\overline{\pi}_nπn​ from (Ω,σ(Hn))(\Omega, \sigma(H_n))(Ω,σ(Hn​)) to (A,A)(\mathsf{A}, \mathscr A)(A,A) defined by π‾n(ω,C)=πn(Hn(ω),C),ω∈Ω, C∈A,\begin{aligned} \overline\pi_n(\omega, C) = \pi_n(H_n(\omega), C), \quad \omega \in \Omega,\, C \in\mathscr A,\end{aligned}πn​(ω,C)=πn​(Hn​(ω),C),ω∈Ω,C∈A,​ is a version of the conditional distribution of AnA_nAn​ given Hn.H_n.Hn​.

  3. The joint distribution of (Hn,An,Xn+1)(H_n, A_n, X_{n+1})(Hn​,An​,Xn+1​) is given by (Pνπ∘(Hn,An)−1)⊗κ.(\mathbb{P}^\pi_\nu \circ (H_n, A_n)^{-1}) \otimes \kappa.(Pνπ​∘(Hn​,An​)−1)⊗κ. More intuitively, by Theorem 4, this means that the stochastic kernel κ‾n\overline\kappa_nκn​ from (Ω,σ(Hn,An))(\Omega, \sigma(H_{n}, A_n))(Ω,σ(Hn​,An​)) to (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr S)(S,S) defined by κ‾n(ω,B)=κ((Xn(ω),An(ω)),B),ω∈Ω, B∈S,\begin{aligned} \overline\kappa_n(\omega, B) = \kappa((X_n(\omega), A_n(\omega)), B), \quad \omega \in \Omega,\, B \in \mathscr S,\end{aligned}κn​(ω,B)=κ((Xn​(ω),An​(ω)),B),ω∈Ω,B∈S,​ is a version of the conditional distribution of Xn+1X_{n+1}Xn+1​ given (Hn,An).(H_n, A_n).(Hn​,An​).

The answer to our question is, of course, yes. At this point recall the Ionescu-Tulcea theorem:

Theorem 6 [Ionescu-Tuclea]: Let {En,En}n≥0\{\mathsf E_n, \mathscr{E}_n\}_{n \ge 0}{En​,En​}n≥0​ be sequence of arbitrary measurable spaces. For each n≥0n \ge 0n≥0, let ηn+1\eta_{n+1}ηn+1​ be a stochastic kernel from (E0×⋯×En,E0⊗⋯⊗En)(\mathsf E_0\times \cdots \times \mathsf E_n, \mathscr{E}_0 \otimes \cdots \otimes \mathscr{E}_n)(E0​×⋯×En​,E0​⊗⋯⊗En​) to (En+1,En+1)(\mathsf E_{n+1}, \mathscr{E}_{n+1})(En+1​,En+1​). Finally, let μ\muμ be a probability measure on (E0,E0)(\mathsf E_{0}, \mathscr{E}_{0})(E0​,E0​). Then there exists a unique probability measure P\mathbb PP on the measurable space (E,E)=(E0×E1×⋯ ,E0⊗E1⊗⋯ )(\mathsf E, \mathscr{E}) = (\mathsf E_0\times \mathsf E_1\times \cdots, \mathscr{E}_0 \otimes \mathscr{E}_1 \otimes \cdots)(E,E)=(E0​×E1​×⋯,E0​⊗E1​⊗⋯) whose value on every cylinder set B=B0×⋯×Bm×Em+1×Em+2×⋯B = B_0 \times \cdots \times B_m \times \mathsf E_{m+1} \times \mathsf E_{m+2} \times \cdotsB=B0​×⋯×Bm​×Em+1​×Em+2​×⋯ for all m≥0m \ge 0m≥0, where Bi∈EiB_i \in \mathscr E_iBi​∈Ei​ for i=0,…,mi = 0, \ldots, mi=0,…,m, is given by
P(B)=∫B0μ(dx0)∫B1η1(x0,dx1)⋯∫Bmηm((x0,x1,…,xn−1),dxn).\begin{aligned} \mathbb P(B) = \int_{B_0} \mu(\mathrm{d}x_0) \int_{B_1} \eta_1(x_0, \mathrm{d}x_1)\cdots \int_{B_m} \eta_m((x_0, x_1, \ldots, x_{n-1}), \mathrm{d}x_n).\end{aligned}P(B)=∫B0​​μ(dx0​)∫B1​​η1​(x0​,dx1​)⋯∫Bm​​ηm​((x0​,x1​,…,xn−1​),dxn​).​
More generally, for any non-negative random variable ZZZ on (E,E)(\mathsf E, \mathscr{E})(E,E) which only depends on the coordinates up to some finite index m≥0m \ge 0m≥0, we have
∫EZ dP=∫B0μ(dx0)∫B1η1(x0,dx1)⋯∫Bmηm((x0,x1,…,xn−1),dxn)Z(x0,…,xm).\begin{aligned} \int_{\mathsf E} Z \, \mathrm{d}\mathbb{P} = \int_{B_0} \mu(\mathrm{d}x_0) \int_{B_1} \eta_1(x_0, \mathrm{d}x_1)\cdots \int_{B_m} \eta_m((x_0, x_1, \ldots, x_{n-1}), \mathrm{d}x_n) Z(x_0, \ldots, x_m).\end{aligned}∫E​ZdP=∫B0​​μ(dx0​)∫B1​​η1​(x0​,dx1​)⋯∫Bm​​ηm​((x0​,x1​,…,xn−1​),dxn​)Z(x0​,…,xm​).​

To this end, define

Ω=(S×A)∞\begin{aligned} \Omega = (\mathsf S \times \mathsf A)^{\infty}\end{aligned}Ω=(S×A)∞​
and F\mathscr{F}F to be the product σ−\sigma-σ−algebra on Ω\OmegaΩ. The elements of Ω\OmegaΩ are sequences of the form ω=(x0,a0,x1,a1,…).\omega = (x_0, a_0, x_1, a_1, \ldots).ω=(x0​,a0​,x1​,a1​,…). Comparing our formulation to the one in Theorem 5, we let E2n\mathsf E_{2n}E2n​ correspond to S\mathsf SS and E2n+1\mathsf E_{2n+1}E2n+1​ correspond to A\mathsf AA for each n≥0.n \ge 0.n≥0. We let μ\muμ correspond to ν.\nu.ν. We let η2n\eta_{2n}η2n​ correspond to the stochastic kernel πn\pi_nπn​ from (S×A)n×S(\mathsf S \times \mathsf A)^n \times \mathsf S(S×A)n×S to A\mathsf AA, and we let η2n+1\eta_{2n+1}η2n+1​ correspond to the stochastic kernel from (S×A)n+1(\mathsf S \times \mathsf A)^{n+1}(S×A)n+1 to S\mathsf SS obtained from κ\kappaκ, for each n≥0.n \ge 0.n≥0. More concretely,
η2n+1((x0,a0,…,xn,an),B):=κ((xn,an),B).\begin{aligned} \eta_{2n+1}((x_0, a_0, \ldots, x_n, a_n), B) := \kappa((x_n, a_n), B).\end{aligned}η2n+1​((x0​,a0​,…,xn​,an​),B):=κ((xn​,an​),B).​

Then Theorem 5 implies that there exists a probability space (Ω,F,Pνπ)(\Omega, \mathscr{F}, \mathbb{P}_{\nu}^{\pi})(Ω,F,Pνπ​) satisfying (10), (11) and (12), where we define the random variables {Xn}n≥0\{X_n\}_{n \ge 0}{Xn​}n≥0​ and {An}n≥0\{A_n\}_{n \ge 0}{An​}n≥0​ by the projection maps:

Ω∋ω=(x0,a0,x1,a1,…)↦Xn(ω):=xn∈S,Ω∋ω=(x0,a0,x1,a1,…)↦An(ω):=an∈A.\begin{aligned} \Omega \ni \omega = (x_0, a_0, x_1, a_1, \ldots)&\mapsto X_n(\omega) := x_n \in \mathsf S, \\ \Omega \ni \omega = (x_0, a_0, x_1, a_1, \ldots)&\mapsto A_n(\omega) := a_n \in \mathsf A. \end{aligned}Ω∋ω=(x0​,a0​,x1​,a1​,…)Ω∋ω=(x0​,a0​,x1​,a1​,…)​↦Xn​(ω):=xn​∈S,↦An​(ω):=an​∈A.​

We denote by Eνπ\mathbb{E}_\nu^\piEνπ​ the expectation operator with respect to the probability space (Ω,F,Pνπ).(\Omega, \mathscr{F}, \mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi).(Ω,F,Pνπ​). If ν=δx\nu = \delta_xν=δx​ is a Dirac measure at x∈S,x \in \mathsf S,x∈S, we will simply write Pxπ\mathbb{P}_x^\piPxπ​ and Exπ\mathbb{E}_x^\piExπ​ for Pδxπ\mathbb{P}_{\delta_x}^\piPδx​π​ and Eδxπ.\mathbb{E}_{\delta_x}^\pi.Eδx​π​.

Note that (1) implies that we can write (11) and (12) as Pνπ[{An∈C}∣σ(Hn)]=πn(Hn,C),C∈A,\begin{aligned} \mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi\left[\{A_n \in C\} \mid \sigma(H_n)\right] = \pi_n(H_n, C), \quad C \in \mathscr A,\end{aligned}Pνπ​[{An​∈C}∣σ(Hn​)]=πn​(Hn​,C),C∈A,​ Pνπ[{Xn+1∈B}∣σ(Hn,An)]=κ((Xn,An),B),B∈S.\begin{aligned} \mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi\left[\{X_{n+1} \in B\} \mid \sigma(H_n, A_n)\right] = \kappa((X_n, A_n), B), \quad B \in \mathscr S.\end{aligned}Pνπ​[{Xn+1​∈B}∣σ(Hn​,An​)]=κ((Xn​,An​),B),B∈S.​

Also notice that because of the constraint (9) on a policy, the probability measure Pνπ\mathbb{P}_\nu^\piPνπ​ is supported on the closure of the set of all possible histories H∞:=S×⟦α⟧∞.\mathsf H_\infty := \mathsf S \times \llbracket \alpha \rrbracket^\infty.H∞​:=S×[[α]]∞.

Definition 14: Given a Markov decision model (S,A,α,κ,r)(\mathsf S, \mathsf A, \alpha, \kappa, r)(S,A,α,κ,r), an initial distribution ν,\nu,ν, and a policy π∈Π,\pi \in \Pi,π∈Π, the associated stochastic process (Ω,F,Pνπ,{Xn}n≥0)(\Omega, \mathscr{F}, \mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi, \{X_n\}_{n \ge 0})(Ω,F,Pνπ​,{Xn​}n≥0​) is called a Markov decision process.
Definition 15: We call {Xn}n≥0\{X_n\}_{n \ge 0}{Xn​}n≥0​ the state process and {An}n≥0\{A_n\}_{n \ge 0}{An​}n≥0​ the action process.

Markov State Process

Although equation (14) looks like a Markov condition, the state process {Xn}\{X_n\}{Xn​} may not be a Markov process because of the dependence on history through the action process. It seems intuitively plausible that if the policy is Markov, then the state process should also be Markov. We prove this now.

Notation: If φ\varphiφ is a stochastic kernel from S\mathsf SS to A\mathsf AA, then for every x∈Sx \in \mathsf Sx∈S, define

r(x,φ):=∫Ar(x,a)φ(x,da), andκ((x,φ),⋅):=∫Aκ((x,a),⋅)φ(x,da).\begin{aligned} r(x,\varphi) &:= \int_{\mathsf A} r(x,a) \varphi(x, \mathrm{d}a), \text{ and} \\ \kappa((x, \varphi), \cdot) &:= \int_{\mathsf A} \kappa((x,a), \cdot) \varphi(x, \mathrm{d}a). \end{aligned}r(x,φ)κ((x,φ),⋅)​:=∫A​r(x,a)φ(x,da), and:=∫A​κ((x,a),⋅)φ(x,da).​

Note that r(⋅,φ)r(\cdot, \varphi)r(⋅,φ) is a measurable function and κ((⋅,φ),⋅)\kappa((\cdot, \varphi), \cdot)κ((⋅,φ),⋅) is a stochastic kernel on S.\mathsf S.S.

Theorem 7: Under the setting of Definition 14, but where the policy π={φn}n≥0∈ΠM\pi = \{\varphi_n\}_{n \ge 0} \in \Pi_Mπ={φn​}n≥0​∈ΠM​, the state process {Xn}n≥0\{X_n\}_{n \ge 0}{Xn​}n≥0​ is a non-homogeneous Markov process with transition kernels {κ((⋅,φn),⋅)}n≥0\{\kappa((\cdot,\varphi_n),\cdot)\}_{n \ge 0}{κ((⋅,φn​),⋅)}n≥0​, i.e., for every B∈SB \in \mathscr SB∈S and n≥0n \ge 0n≥0, almost surely Pνπ[{Xn+1∈B}∣σ(X0,X1,…,Xn)]=κ((Xn,φn),B)=Pνπ[{Xn+1∈B}∣σ(Xn)].\begin{aligned} \mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi\left[\{X_{n+1} \in B\} \mid \sigma(X_0, X_1, \ldots, X_n)\right]= \kappa((X_n, \varphi_n), B)= \mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi\left[\{X_{n+1} \in B\} \mid \sigma(X_n)\right].\end{aligned}Pνπ​[{Xn+1​∈B}∣σ(X0​,X1​,…,Xn​)]=κ((Xn​,φn​),B)=Pνπ​[{Xn+1​∈B}∣σ(Xn​)].​ In particular, if π∈ΠS\pi \in \Pi_{S}π∈ΠS​, then the state process is a homogeneous Markov process.

Let us start by fixing any policy π={πn}n≥0∈Π\pi = \{\pi_n\}_{n \ge 0} \in \Piπ={πn​}n≥0​∈Π and any B∈S.B \in \mathscr S.B∈S. Then

Pνπ[{Xn+1∈B}∣σ(Hn)]=Eνπ[Pνπ[{Xn+1∈B}∣σ(Hn,An)]∣σ(Hn)]=Eνπ[κ((Xn,An),B)∣σ(Hn)]=∫Aκ((Xn,a),B) πn(Hn,da),\begin{aligned} \mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi\left[\{X_{n+1} \in B\} \mid \sigma(H_n)\right] &=\mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi\left[\mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi\left[\{X_{n+1} \in B\} \mid \sigma(H_n, A_n)\right] \mid \sigma(H_n)\right] \\ &=\mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi\left[\kappa((X_n, A_n), B) \mid \sigma(H_n)\right] \\ &= \int_{\mathsf A} \kappa((X_n, a), B) \,\pi_n(H_n, \mathrm{d}a), \end{aligned}Pνπ​[{Xn+1​∈B}∣σ(Hn​)]​=Eνπ​[Pνπ​[{Xn+1​∈B}∣σ(Hn​,An​)]∣σ(Hn​)]=Eνπ​[κ((Xn​,An​),B)∣σ(Hn​)]=∫A​κ((Xn​,a),B)πn​(Hn​,da),​

where the first equality follows from the tower rule for conditional expectation, the second equality follows from (14), and the third equality follows from (11) and (5).

Now if π={φn}n≥0∈ΠM\pi = \{\varphi_n\}_{n \ge 0} \in \Pi_Mπ={φn​}n≥0​∈ΠM​, then the equation above becomes Pνπ[{Xn+1∈B}∣σ(Hn)]=∫Aκ((Xn,a),B) φn(Xn,da)=κ((Xn,φn),B).\begin{aligned} \mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi\left[\{X_{n+1} \in B\} \mid \sigma(H_n)\right] =\int_{\mathsf A} \kappa((X_n, a), B) \,\varphi_n(X_n, \mathrm{d}a) = \kappa((X_n, \varphi_n), B).\end{aligned}Pνπ​[{Xn+1​∈B}∣σ(Hn​)]=∫A​κ((Xn​,a),B)φn​(Xn​,da)=κ((Xn​,φn​),B).​

Then using the tower rule again, substituting equation (16), and using the fact that κ((Xn,φn),B)\kappa((X_n, \varphi_n), B)κ((Xn​,φn​),B) is σ(Xn)−\sigma(X_n)-σ(Xn​)−measurable, the LHS of equation (15) can be written

Pνπ[{Xn+1∈B}∣σ(X0,X1,…,Xn)]=Eνπ[Pνπ[{Xn+1∈B}∣σ(Hn)]∣σ(X0,X1,…,Xn)]=Eνπ[κ((Xn,φn),B)∣σ(X0,X1,…,Xn)]=κ((Xn,φn),B),\begin{aligned} \mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi\left[\{X_{n+1} \in B\} \mid \sigma(X_0, X_1, \ldots, X_n)\right] &= \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi\left[\mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi\left[\{X_{n+1} \in B\} \mid \sigma(H_n)\right] \mid \sigma(X_0, X_1, \ldots, X_n)\right] \\ &= \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi\left[\kappa((X_n, \varphi_n), B) \mid \sigma(X_0, X_1, \ldots, X_n)\right] \\ &= \kappa((X_n, \varphi_n), B), \end{aligned}Pνπ​[{Xn+1​∈B}∣σ(X0​,X1​,…,Xn​)]​=Eνπ​[Pνπ​[{Xn+1​∈B}∣σ(Hn​)]∣σ(X0​,X1​,…,Xn​)]=Eνπ​[κ((Xn​,φn​),B)∣σ(X0​,X1​,…,Xn​)]=κ((Xn​,φn​),B),​
showing the first equality in equation (15). Similarly we can write
Pνπ[{Xn+1∈B}∣σ(Xn)]=Eνπ[Pνπ[{Xn+1∈B}∣σ(Hn)]∣σ(Xn)]=Eνπ[κ((Xn,φn),B)∣σ(Xn)]=κ((Xn,φn),B),\begin{aligned} \mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi\left[\{X_{n+1} \in B\} \mid \sigma(X_n)\right] &= \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi\left[\mathbb{P}_\nu^\pi\left[\{X_{n+1} \in B\} \mid \sigma(H_n)\right] \mid \sigma(X_n)\right] \\ &= \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi\left[\kappa((X_n, \varphi_n), B) \mid \sigma(X_n)\right] \\ &= \kappa((X_n, \varphi_n), B), \end{aligned}Pνπ​[{Xn+1​∈B}∣σ(Xn​)]​=Eνπ​[Pνπ​[{Xn+1​∈B}∣σ(Hn​)]∣σ(Xn​)]=Eνπ​[κ((Xn​,φn​),B)∣σ(Xn​)]=κ((Xn​,φn​),B),​
showing the second equality in equation (15).

OPTIMAL POLICIES

Until now we have implicitly assumed that the total period of time over which the system is observed is infinite. In many situations we are interested in the finite horizon problem. So let us denote by T∈N∪{+∞}T \in \mathbb N \cup \{+\infty\}T∈N∪{+∞} the length of this planning or control horizon. This gives a way to classify Markov decision processes—finite horizon or infinite horizon problems.

Markov decision processes can also be classified according to the performance criterion used.

Performance Criteria

Given a Markov decision model and an initial distribution, we have a choice over which policy to choose. We will need to define what performance criterion we are optimizing for to choose an optimal policy. Suppose we have a class ΠA\Pi_AΠA​ of admissible policies, where ΠA\Pi_AΠA​ could be Π\PiΠ or ΠDM\Pi_{DM}ΠDM​ or any other class we discussed above. The performance criterion measures how “good” a policy is. There are two performance criteria which are common in the literature: expected total reward and the long-run average expected reward per unit time.

Expected Total Reward

Definition 16: Given an initial state X0=x∈SX_0 = x \in \mathsf SX0​=x∈S, a policy π∈ΠA\pi \in \Pi_Aπ∈ΠA​, and a discount factor β∈(0,1]\beta \in (0,1]β∈(0,1], the expected total reward is given by
J(π,x):=Exπ[∑n=0Tβnr(Xn,An,Xn+1)]\begin{aligned} J(\pi, x) := \mathbb{E}^\pi_{x}\left[ \sum_{n=0}^T \beta^n r(X_n, A_n, X_{n+1}) \right]\end{aligned}J(π,x):=Exπ​[n=0∑T​βnr(Xn​,An​,Xn+1​)]​
if T=+∞,T = +\infty,T=+∞, and
J(π,x):=Exπ[∑n=0T−1βnr(Xn,An,Xn+1)+rT(XT)]\begin{aligned} J(\pi, x) := \mathbb{E}_x^\pi \left[ \sum_{n=0}^{T-1} \beta^n r(X_n, A_n, X_{n+1}) + r_T(X_T) \right]\end{aligned}J(π,x):=Exπ​[n=0∑T−1​βnr(Xn​,An​,Xn+1​)+rT​(XT​)]​
if T∈N,T \in \mathbb N,T∈N, with rN ⁣:S→[−∞,∞)r_N \colon \mathsf S \to [-\infty, \infty)rN​:S→[−∞,∞), a measurable function, denoting the terminal reward.

Recall that Exπ\mathbb{E}_x^\piExπ​ simply means Eδxπ.\mathbb{E}_{\delta_x}^\pi.Eδx​π​. In this setting it is usually assumed that the reward function rrr is bounded, so that J(π,x)J(\pi, x)J(π,x) is a bounded function.

We use J∗J^*J∗ to denote the value function

J∗(x):=sup⁡π∈ΠAJ(π,x),x∈S.\begin{aligned} J^*(x) := \sup_{\pi \in \Pi_A} J(\pi, x), \quad x \in \mathsf S.\end{aligned}J∗(x):=π∈ΠA​sup​J(π,x),x∈S.​

The problem is to find (if it exists!) a policy π∗∈ΠA\pi^* \in \Pi_Aπ∗∈ΠA​ such that

J(π∗,x)=J∗(x),∀ x∈S.\begin{aligned} J(\pi^*, x) = J^*(x), \quad \forall \; x \in \mathsf S.\end{aligned}J(π∗,x)=J∗(x),∀x∈S.​

Long-run Average Expected Reward

Definition 17: Given an initial state x0=x∈Sx_0 = x \in \mathsf Sx0​=x∈S and a policy π∈ΠA\pi \in \Pi_Aπ∈ΠA​, the long-run average expected reward per unit time is given by
J(π,x):=lim inf⁡m→∞1mExπ[∑n=0mr(Xn,An)].\begin{aligned} J(\pi, x) := \liminf_{m \to \infty} \frac{1}{m} \mathbb{E}^\pi_{x}\left[ \sum_{n=0}^m r(X_n, A_n) \right].\end{aligned}J(π,x):=m→∞liminf​m1​Exπ​[n=0∑m​r(Xn​,An​)].​

We could have taken lim sup⁡\limsuplimsup, and both give different results, but the lim inf⁡\liminfliminf case is easier to handle. Intuitively, the lim inf⁡\liminfliminf case gives a more pessimistic picture, while the lim sup⁡\limsuplimsup gives a more optimistic picture. See the survey (ABFGM, 1993) for a detailed treatment of this performance criterion. We will be focusing on the expected total reward next.

The choice of the performance criterion is application dependent. For example, if the future rewards are to be valued less than immediate rewards, then using expected total reward with β<1\beta < 1β<1 would make sense. On the other hand, if the long term behaviour is to be studied and initial transient period is to be ignored, then using the long-run average expected reward makes sense.

Deterministic Markov Policy

Suppose that we are in the finite horizon with the expected total reward regime. Assume that the terminal reward is 000 for simplicity, and that the

reward function r ⁣:S×A→R is bounded.\begin{aligned} \text{reward function } r \colon \mathsf S \times \mathsf A \to \mathbb R \text{ is bounded.}\end{aligned}reward function r:S×A→R is bounded.​

As the notation suggests, we have also implicitly assumed that α(x)=A\alpha(x) = \mathsf Aα(x)=A for every x∈S.x \in \mathsf S.x∈S. In this setting we want to compare the classes ΠD\Pi_DΠD​ and ΠDM\Pi_{DM}ΠDM​ of policies. We claim that there is no loss of optimality in restricting attention to the smaller class ΠDM\Pi_{DM}ΠDM​ of deterministic Markov policies. This is a surprising result! Policies in ΠD\Pi_DΠD​ can depend on the entire history in a very complicated manner, and it is not clear why a deterministic Markov policy should be just as good. I came across this result in a blog post by Maxim Raginsky (Raginsky, 2010). The key result which we will use is from a 1964 paper by David Blackwell (Blackwell, 1964). We state this result without proof.

Theorem 8 [Blackwell]: Let S,T,\mathsf S,\mathsf T,S,T, and A\mathsf AA be standard Borel spaces, let Q\mathbb QQ be any probability measure on the product space S×T\mathsf S \times \mathsf TS×T, and let R ⁣:S×A→RR \colon \mathsf S \times \mathsf A \to \mathbb RR:S×A→R be a bounded measurable reward function. Then for any measurable function g ⁣:S×T→Ag \colon \mathsf S \times \mathsf T \to \mathsf Ag:S×T→A there exists another measurable function f ⁣:S→Af \colon \mathsf S \to \mathsf Af:S→A such that
∫S×TR(x,f(x)) Q(dx,dy)≥∫S×TR(x,g(x,y)) Q(dx,dy).\begin{aligned} \int_{\mathsf S \times \mathsf T} R(x, f(x)) \, \mathbb{Q}(\mathrm{d}x, \mathrm{d}y) \ge \int_{\mathsf S \times \mathsf T} R(x, g(x,y))\, \mathbb{Q}(\mathrm{d}x, \mathrm{d}y).\end{aligned}∫S×T​R(x,f(x))Q(dx,dy)≥∫S×T​R(x,g(x,y))Q(dx,dy).​

Let us now state and prove our theorem. Instead of fixing an initial state xxx as above in the total expected reward function, we let the initial distribution be any probability measure ν\nuν on S.\mathscr S.S.

Theorem 9: For any policy π∈ΠD\pi \in \Pi_Dπ∈ΠD​, there exists a policy τ∈ΠDM\tau \in \Pi_{DM}τ∈ΠDM​ such that J(τ)≥J(π).J(\tau) \ge J(\pi).J(τ)≥J(π).

Here, J(π)J(\pi)J(π), of course, denotes

J(π):=Eνπ[∑n=0N−1r(Xn,An)].\begin{aligned} J(\pi) := \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[ \sum_{n=0}^{N-1} r(X_n, A_n) \right].\end{aligned}J(π):=Eνπ​[n=0∑N−1​r(Xn​,An​)].​

Before we prove the theorem, let us establish two lemmas. The first lemma states that the theorem holds true for N=2.N=2.N=2.

Lemma 2: If N=2N=2N=2, then for any policy π=(π0,π1)∈ΠD\pi = (\pi_0, \pi_1) \in \Pi_Dπ=(π0​,π1​)∈ΠD​ there exists a policy τ=(τ0,τ1)∈ΠDM\tau = (\tau_0, \tau_1) \in \Pi_{DM}τ=(τ0​,τ1​)∈ΠDM​ such that J(τ)≥J(π).J(\tau) \ge J(\pi).J(τ)≥J(π).
Writing J(π)J(\pi)J(π) explicitly,
J(π)=Eνπ[r(X0,π0(X0))]+Eνπ[r(X1,π1(X0,π0(X0),X1))],\begin{aligned} J(\pi) = \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[ r(X_0, \pi_0(X_0)) \right] + \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[ r(X_1, \pi_1(X_0, \pi_0(X_0), X_1)) \right],\end{aligned}J(π)=Eνπ​[r(X0​,π0​(X0​))]+Eνπ​[r(X1​,π1​(X0​,π0​(X0​),X1​))],​
we note that the first term of RHS does not depend on π1.\pi_1.π1​. Using Blackwell’s theorem for the second term, with S,A\mathsf S, \mathsf AS,A being the same, T=A×S\mathsf T=\mathsf A \times \mathsf ST=A×S, g=π1g = \pi_1g=π1​, Q\mathbb QQ being the product of ν\nuν with the kernel determined by the function π0\pi_0π0​ and the kernel κ\kappaκ, as noted in the section of Policy, and R=rR=rR=r, we conclude that there exists a measurable function τ1 ⁣:S→A\tau_1 \colon \mathsf S \to \mathsf Aτ1​:S→A such that
Eντ[r(X1,τ1(X1))]≥Eνπ[r(X1,π1(X0,π0(X0),X1))].\begin{aligned} \mathbb{E}_\nu^\tau \left[ r(X_1,\tau_1(X_1)) \right] \ge \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[ r(X_1, \pi_1(X_0, \pi_0(X_0), X_1)) \right].\end{aligned}Eντ​[r(X1​,τ1​(X1​))]≥Eνπ​[r(X1​,π1​(X0​,π0​(X0​),X1​))].​
The claim follows after noting that we can take τ0=π0.\tau_0 = \pi_0.τ0​=π0​.

The next lemma states that when N=3N=3N=3 and the last policy π2\pi_2π2​ is Markov, then we can choose even the second policy to be Markov. More precisely,

Lemma 3: If N=3N=3N=3 and π=(π0,π1,π2)∈ΠD\pi = (\pi_0, \pi_1, \pi_2) \in \Pi_Dπ=(π0​,π1​,π2​)∈ΠD​ is such that π2 ⁣:S×A×S×A×S→A\pi_2 \colon \mathsf S \times \mathsf A \times \mathsf S \times \mathsf A \times \mathsf S \to \mathsf Aπ2​:S×A×S×A×S→A is constant except in the last argument S\mathsf SS, then there is a policy τ∈ΠDM\tau \in \Pi_{DM}τ∈ΠDM​ such that J(τ)≥J(π).J(\tau) \ge J(\pi).J(τ)≥J(π).
We let τ=(τ0,τ1,τ2)∈ΠDM\tau = (\tau_0, \tau_1, \tau_2) \in \Pi_{DM}τ=(τ0​,τ1​,τ2​)∈ΠDM​ be such that τ0=π0\tau_0 = \pi_0τ0​=π0​, τ2=π2\tau_2 = \pi_2τ2​=π2​, and define τ1\tau_1τ1​ as follows. Writing J(π)J(\pi)J(π) explicitly, J(π)=Eνπ[r(X0,π0(X0))]+Eνπ[r(X1,π1(X0,π0(X0),X1))]+Eνπ[r(X2,π2(X2))],\begin{aligned} J(\pi) = \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[ r(X_0, \pi_0(X_0)) \right] + \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[ r(X_1, \pi_1(X_0, \pi_0(X_0), X_1)) \right] + \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[ r(X_2, \pi_2(X_2)) \right],\end{aligned}J(π)=Eνπ​[r(X0​,π0​(X0​))]+Eνπ​[r(X1​,π1​(X0​,π0​(X0​),X1​))]+Eνπ​[r(X2​,π2​(X2​))],​ where we ignored the irrelevant terms in π2\pi_2π2​, we note that the first term does not depend on π1\pi_1π1​ and π2.\pi_2.π2​. Since X2X_2X2​ depends on the action π1(X0,π0(X0),X1)\pi_1(X_0, \pi_0(X_0), X_1)π1​(X0​,π0​(X0​),X1​) taken at time 111, both the second and the third terms depend on π1.\pi_1.π1​. Focusing on the third term,
Eνπ[r(X2,π2(X2))]=Eνπ[Eνπ[r(X2,π2(X2))∣X1,A1]]=:Eνπ[h(X1,A1)].\begin{aligned} \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[ r(X_2, \pi_2(X_2)) \right] = \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[\mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[ r(X_2, \pi_2(X_2)) \mid X_1, A_1 \right]\right] =: \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[h(X_1, A_1)\right].\end{aligned}Eνπ​[r(X2​,π2​(X2​))]=Eνπ​[Eνπ​[r(X2​,π2​(X2​))∣X1​,A1​]]=:Eνπ​[h(X1​,A1​)].​
Using (5) and (14) we can write,
h(X1,A1)=∫Sr(x2,π2(x2))κ((X1,A1),dx2).\begin{aligned} h(X_1, A_1) = \int_{\mathsf S} r(x_2, \pi_2(x_2)) \kappa((X_1, A_1), \mathrm{d}x_2).\end{aligned}h(X1​,A1​)=∫S​r(x2​,π2​(x2​))κ((X1​,A1​),dx2​).​
Then the function hhh is measurable and bounded. Now define
R(x,a)=r(x,a)+h(x,a),\begin{aligned} R(x,a) = r(x,a) + h(x,a),\end{aligned}R(x,a)=r(x,a)+h(x,a),​
which is also measurable and bounded, and note that by combining the previous results we can write the last two two terms of RHS of (17) as
Eνπ[r(X1,π1(X0,π0(X0),X1))]+Eνπ[r(X2,π2(X2))]=Eνπ[R(X1,π1(X0,π0(X0),X1))].\begin{aligned} \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[ r(X_1, \pi_1(X_0, \pi_0(X_0), X_1)) \right] + \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[ r(X_2, \pi_2(X_2)) \right] = \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[ R(X_1, \pi_1(X_0, \pi_0(X_0), X_1)) \right].\end{aligned}Eνπ​[r(X1​,π1​(X0​,π0​(X0​),X1​))]+Eνπ​[r(X2​,π2​(X2​))]=Eνπ​[R(X1​,π1​(X0​,π0​(X0​),X1​))].​
Applying Blackwell’s theorem, with S,A,R\mathsf S, \mathsf A, RS,A,R being the same, T=A×S\mathsf T=\mathsf A \times \mathsf ST=A×S, g=π1g = \pi_1g=π1​, and Q\mathbb QQ being the product of ν\nuν with the kernel determined by the function π0\pi_0π0​ and the kernel κ\kappaκ, as noted in the section of Policy, we conclude that there exists a measurable function τ1 ⁣:S→A\tau_1 \colon \mathsf S \to \mathsf Aτ1​:S→A such that
Eντ[R(X1,τ1(X1))]≥Eνπ[R(X1,π1(X0,π0(X0),X1))].\begin{aligned} \mathbb{E}_\nu^\tau \left[ R(X_1,\tau_1(X_1)) \right] \ge \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[ R(X_1, \pi_1(X_0, \pi_0(X_0), X_1)) \right].\end{aligned}Eντ​[R(X1​,τ1​(X1​))]≥Eνπ​[R(X1​,π1​(X0​,π0​(X0​),X1​))].​
But note that we can write
Eντ[R(X1,τ1(X1))]=Eντ[r(X1,τ1(X0,π0(X0),X1))]+Eνπ[r(X2,τ2(X2))],\begin{aligned} \mathbb{E}_\nu^\tau \left[ R(X_1,\tau_1(X_1)) \right] = \mathbb{E}_\nu^\tau \left[ r(X_1, \tau_1(X_0, \pi_0(X_0), X_1)) \right] + \mathbb{E}_\nu^\pi \left[ r(X_2, \tau_2(X_2)) \right],\end{aligned}Eντ​[R(X1​,τ1​(X1​))]=Eντ​[r(X1​,τ1​(X0​,π0​(X0​),X1​))]+Eνπ​[r(X2​,τ2​(X2​))],​
and thus J(τ)≥J(π)J(\tau) \ge J(\pi)J(τ)≥J(π), and the lemma is proved.

Finally, we come to the proof of Theorem 9.

(of Theorem 9) Let π∈ΠD.\pi \in \Pi_D.π∈ΠD​. The cases N=1N=1N=1 and N=2N=2N=2 follow from the lemmas 2 and 3. For N≥3N \ge 3N≥3 we analyze as follows:

View π\piπ as a two-step policy ((π0,…,πN−2),πN−1)((\pi_0, \ldots, \pi_{N-2}), \pi_{N-1})((π0​,…,πN−2​),πN−1​) in an alternative two-step MDP. Then by Lemma 2, we can assume that πN−1\pi_{N-1}πN−1​ is a Markov policy.

Now view π\piπ as a three-step policy ((π0,…,πN−3),πN−2,πN−1)((\pi_0, \ldots, \pi_{N-3}), \pi_{N-2}, \pi_{N-1})((π0​,…,πN−3​),πN−2​,πN−1​). The policy in the third time-step πN−1\pi_{N-1}πN−1​ is Markov, and so we can apply Lemma 3 to conclude that πN−2\pi_{N-2}πN−2​ is also Markov.

We continue in a similar manner for smaller indices k=N−3,N−4,…k = N-3, N-4, \ldotsk=N−3,N−4,… to get our result.

This can be generalized to the class of all, and not necessarily deterministic, policies. I have not verified the proof, but it can be found in (Derman and Strauch, 1966) or Section 3.8 of (Dynkin and Yushkevich, 1979).

Dynamic Programming

Suppose, again, that we are in the finite horizon with the expected total reward regime. When can we say that there exists an optimal policy which is a deterministic Markov policy? Making some assumptions with regards to measurable selections, we can find, using dynamic programming, the optimal policy and the value function.

Theorem 10: Define the real-valued functions JN,JN−1,…,J0J_N, J_{N-1}, \ldots, J_0JN​,JN−1​,…,J0​ on S\mathsf SS inductively as follows: for each x∈S,x \in \mathsf S,x∈S,
JN(x):=rN(x),Jn(x):=sup⁡{r(x,a)+∫SJn+1(y) κ((x,a),dy) ∣ a∈α(x)},n=N−1,N−2,…,0.\begin{aligned} J_N(x) &:= r_N(x), \\ J_n(x) &:= \sup \left\{\left. r(x,a) + \int_{\mathsf S} J_{n+1}(y) \,\kappa((x,a), \mathrm{d}y) \; \right\vert \; a \in \alpha(x) \right\}, \quad n = N-1, N-2, \ldots, 0. \end{aligned}JN​(x)Jn​(x)​:=rN​(x),:=sup{r(x,a)+∫S​Jn+1​(y)κ((x,a),dy)∣∣​a∈α(x)},n=N−1,N−2,…,0.​
Suppose that these functions are measurable and that, for each n=0,…,N−1n = 0, \ldots, N-1n=0,…,N−1, there exists a measurable selector fn ⁣:S→Af_n \colon \mathsf S \to \mathsf Afn​:S→A satisfying fn(x)∈α(x)f_n(x) \in \alpha(x)fn​(x)∈α(x) for all x∈Sx \in \mathsf Sx∈S (or equivalently ⟦fn⟧⊆⟦α⟧\llbracket f_n \rrbracket \subseteq \llbracket \alpha \rrbracket[[fn​]]⊆[[α]]), and that fn(x)f_n(x)fn​(x) attains the maximum in the supremum above, i.e.,
Jn(x)=r(x,fn(x))+∫SJn+1(y) κ((x,fn(x)),dy),∀ x∈S, n=0,…,N−1.\begin{aligned} J_n(x) = r(x,f_n(x)) + \int_{\mathsf S} J_{n+1}(y) \,\kappa((x, f_n(x)), \mathrm{d}y), \quad \forall \, x \in \mathsf S,\, n = 0, \ldots, N-1.\end{aligned}Jn​(x)=r(x,fn​(x))+∫S​Jn+1​(y)κ((x,fn​(x)),dy),∀x∈S,n=0,…,N−1.​
Then the deterministic Markov policy π∗:=(f0,…,fN−1)\pi^* := (f_0, \ldots, f_{N-1})π∗:=(f0​,…,fN−1​) is optimal, and the value function J∗J^*J∗ equals J0.J_0.J0​.
Let π=(π0,…,πN−1)∈Π\pi = (\pi_0, \ldots, \pi_{N-1}) \in \Piπ=(π0​,…,πN−1​)∈Π be an arbitrary policy, and for n=0,…,N−1n = 0, \ldots, N-1n=0,…,N−1 let Rn(π,x)R_n(\pi, x)Rn​(π,x) be the corresponding expected total cost from time nnn to the terminal time NNN, given that Xn=xX_n = xXn​=x. That is, Rn(π,x):=Exπ[r(x,An)+∑m=n+1N−1r(Xm,Am)+rN(XN)].\begin{aligned} R_n(\pi, x) := \mathbb{E}_x^\pi \left[ r(x, A_n) + \sum_{m=n+1}^{N-1} r(X_m, A_m) + r_N(X_N) \right].\end{aligned}Rn​(π,x):=Exπ​[r(x,An​)+m=n+1∑N−1​r(Xm​,Am​)+rN​(XN​)].​ Also let RN(π,x):=rN(x).R_N(\pi, x) := r_N(x).RN​(π,x):=rN​(x). Note that we have
R0(π,x)=J(π,x).\begin{aligned} R_0(\pi, x) = J(\pi, x).\end{aligned}R0​(π,x)=J(π,x).​
To prove the theorem it is sufficient to show that, for all x∈Sx \in \mathsf Sx∈S and n=0,…,Nn = 0, \ldots, Nn=0,…,N, Rn(π,x)≤Jn(x) and Rn(π∗,x)=Jn(x).\begin{aligned} R_n(\pi, x) \le J_n(x) \text{ and } R_n(\pi^*, x) = J_n(x).\end{aligned}Rn​(π,x)≤Jn​(x) and Rn​(π∗,x)=Jn​(x).​ (19) holds for n=Nn = Nn=N by definition. We proceed by induction in the backward direction. Assume that for some k∈{N−1,…,0}k \in \{N-1, \ldots, 0\}k∈{N−1,…,0},
Rk+1(π,x)≤Jk+1(x),∀ x∈S.\begin{aligned} R_{k+1}(\pi, x) \le J_{k+1}(x), \quad \forall \, x \in \mathsf S.\end{aligned}Rk+1​(π,x)≤Jk+1​(x),∀x∈S.​
Then by (18), (5), (13) and (14), Rk(π,x)=Exπ[r(x,Ak)+∑m=k+1N−1r(Xm,Am)+rN(XN)]=∫A[r(x,a)+∫SRk+1(π,y)κ((x,a),dy)]πk(x,da)≤∫A[r(x,a)+∫SJk+1(y)κ((x,a),dy)]πk(x,da)≤sup⁡{r(x,a)+∫SJk+1(y)κ((x,a),dy) ∣ a∈α(x)}=Jk(x).\begin{aligned} R_k(\pi, x) &= \mathbb{E}_x^\pi \left[ r(x, A_k) + \sum_{m=k+1}^{N-1} r(X_m, A_m) + r_N(X_N) \right] \\ &= \int_{\mathsf A} \left[ r(x,a) + \int_{\mathsf S} R_{k+1}(\pi, y) \kappa((x,a), \mathrm{d}y) \right] \pi_k(x, \mathrm{d}a) \\ &\le \int_{\mathsf A} \left[ r(x,a) + \int_{\mathsf S} J_{k+1}(y) \kappa((x,a), \mathrm{d}y) \right] \pi_k(x, \mathrm{d}a) \\ &\le \sup \left\{\left. r(x,a) + \int_{\mathsf S} J_{k+1}(y) \kappa((x,a), \mathrm{d}y) \; \right\vert \; a \in \alpha(x) \right\} \\ &= J_k(x).\end{aligned}Rk​(π,x)​=Exπ​[r(x,Ak​)+m=k+1∑N−1​r(Xm​,Am​)+rN​(XN​)]=∫A​[r(x,a)+∫S​Rk+1​(π,y)κ((x,a),dy)]πk​(x,da)≤∫A​[r(x,a)+∫S​Jk+1​(y)κ((x,a),dy)]πk​(x,da)≤sup{r(x,a)+∫S​Jk+1​(y)κ((x,a),dy)∣∣​a∈α(x)}=Jk​(x).​ This proves the first claim in (19) for all n=0,…,N.n = 0, \ldots, N.n=0,…,N. Proceeding in a similar manner for π=π∗\pi = \pi^*π=π∗, where the first inequality in (20) becomes an equality by the induction hypothesis, and the second inequality in (20) becomes an equality by the structure of π∗\pi^*π∗, we conclude the second claim in (19) also.

The equation defining JnJ_nJn​’s in the theorem statement is known as the dynamic programming equation.

EPILOGUE

It would be remiss of me to not mention the encyclopaedic reference (Bertsekas and Shreve, 1978). I also really liked the book (Hernández-Lerma and Lasserre, 1996), which has the advantage of being short. Next, I would be interested in learning reinforcement learning, where MDPs play a foundational role.
